text: Mr. Spicer: Good afternoon, everybody.
I hope those who celebrated had a great
Easter holiday and have had a chance to go out
and check out the activity on the South Lawn.
We&#39;ve got a few waves still to go.
The President and the First Lady welcomed
thousands of families here to the White House
this morning for the 139th Annual Easter Egg Roll.
When it&#39;s all said and done, we will have had
thousands of guests, including many active-duty
military, veterans, families, children from
local schools, patients from local children&#39;s
hospitals, all here to share in this historic event.
Right about now, the President is finishing up
his regular meeting with the Secretary of State.
The Vice President, of course, is currently
on a 10-day trip visiting South Korea, Japan, Indonesia,
and Australia.
While in South Korea, the Vice President
participated in an Easter church service with both
American and South Korean servicemembers and their
families, and has been holding bilateral meetings
with representatives of the South Korean government.
The Vice President is delivering a message
to the people of the Republic of Korea on behalf
of the President that even in these troubled times,
the United States stands with them for a free
and secure future.
Under President Trump, our ironclad alliance will be
even stronger, our nations will be safer,
and the Asia Pacific region will be more secure.
From South Korea, the Vice President will head to Japan.
I&#39;ll continue to provide updates as they warrant
during the Vice President&#39;s trip throughout the rest of the week.
Looking ahead, tomorrow the President heads
to Wisconsin, where he&#39;ll talk about his &quot;Buy America,
Hire America&quot; agenda at Snap-on Tools in Kenosha, Wisconsin.
For those of you who aren&#39;t aware, Snap-on
is a prime example of a company that builds American-made
tools with American workers for U.S. taxpayers.
We&#39;ll be having a background briefing here
in this room, later this afternoon, with senior
administration officials regarding the details
of the trip.
Further guidance should be coming out
in your inboxes momentarily.
On Wednesday, the President will sign
the Veterans Choice Program Extension and Improvement Act.
The President is proud to sign this legislation,
which passed unanimously by the Senate earlier this month.
The bill ensures that veterans have certainty
and continuity of care while this administration
works with Congress to develop a plan that
reforms the VA system and gives our nation&#39;s heroes
the care that they deserve.
He&#39;ll also host the New England Patriots this
Wednesday to congratulate them on their fifth
Super Bowl win.
And, on Thursday, the Prime Minister of Italy
will be here for an official visit.
And with that, I&#39;ll kick it off to the birthday boy,
Mr. Jim Acosta.
The Press: I&#39;ll take it.
Thank you, Sean.
Does the President have a red line when it comes
to North Korea that, if they cross it, they will bring
about some kind of military response from the U.S.?
Mr. Spicer: I think when we talked about the use
of red lines in the past with respect to Syria --
the President&#39;s red line -- that drawing red lines hasn&#39;t really
worked in the past.
He holds his cards close to the vest, and you&#39;re
not going to see him telegraphing how he&#39;s going
to respond to any military or other
situation going forward.
That&#39;s just something that he believes has not served
us well in the past.
We did this with Mosul, where we started to talk
about what the action will be months in advance.
And it really gives the intended recipient
of action a heads-up as to what&#39;s going on.
So, I don&#39;t think that you&#39;re going to see the
President drawing red lines in the sand,
but I think that the action that he took in Syria shows that,
when appropriate, this President will take decisive action.
The Press: Just to follow up on that, Syria is one thing
and North Korea is quite another, when they
have nuclear ambitions the way that they do.
When you talk about, &quot;Well, we did this to
Syria and we did this to Afghanistan,&quot; is that
being a little too loose with bombastic rhetoric?
Mr. Spicer: No, no, no.
And again, please don&#39;t read too much into that
in terms of trying to make an analogy on the action;
I think it&#39;s quite the opposite.
But I think with respect to North Korea in particular,
the President had a really good meeting
with President Xi down in Mar-a-Lago where I think
he&#39;s spoken extensively about the relationship
that they made down there and that they continue
to work to improve.
And the results of that are paying off.
I think you see China playing a much more active
role with respect to North Korea both politically
and economically, that they can continue to apply pressure
to achieve results.
And I think we&#39;re going to continue to urge China
to exhibit its influence in the region to get better results.
The Press: But North Korea did launch that missile.
They did launch it.
Mr. Spicer: I understand that.
And it failed.
We&#39;re well aware of what&#39;s going on.
We monitored that situation.
The President was kept up to date, as you know.
But I think that we&#39;re going to continue to work
with China in particular to help find a way forward on this.
John.
The Press: Thanks a lot, Sean.
The President, as you just mentioned, has spoken
about this relationship that he&#39;s developed
with President Xi, where President Xi would be
leaning on the North Korean government
to prevent the kind of attempted missile launches,
like we saw over the weekend.
It seems as if that effort in terms of leaning on
North Korea did not work.
In addition to that, the Vice Foreign Minister
of North Korea said to the BBC today that North Korea
will test its missiles on a weekly, a monthly,
and a yearly basis.
So, my question is, what kind of pressure is China
putting on North Korea?
Mr. Spicer: Well, again, I think this goes back
to the nut of what Jim was asking, which is, I think
for us to telegraph what we&#39;re going to do or what
we&#39;re going to ask others to do would not be a smart
strategy to lay it all out in public.
But I think that if you realize -- for example,
on the economic side of things, China is the
number-one importer of North Korean coal.
I think to see them curtail some of that has
a real economic impact on the region.
There&#39;s a lot of economic and political pressure
points that I think China can utilize, and we&#39;ve
been very encouraged with the direction
in which they&#39;re going.
The Press: But North Korea is essentially, just based
upon what they tried to do over the weekend, thumbing
its nose at even China because of what they
attempted to do.
Mr. Spicer: And I understand that question.
I think we&#39;re just not there yet.
We&#39;ve got a lot of tools left and a lot
of conversations that are ongoing.
But let&#39;s not get ahead of ourselves.
I think we&#39;ve had a very productive direction that
we&#39;ve seen China move in, and I think there&#39;s an
agreement, I think by everyone so far, that
a nuclear capable North Korea is not in anybody&#39;s
best interest.
And I think we&#39;re going to continue to work with
the Chinese in particular on this case.
Kaitlan.
The Press: Thanks, Sean.
What was their view of the White House visitor logs?
What&#39;s the extent of that review?
Mr. Spicer: I&#39;m sorry, what was --
The Press: What was the extent of their view
of the White House visitor logs?
What made you change your mind to not continue
releasing them?
Mr. Spicer: I think as was noted on Friday, we&#39;re
following the same policy that every administration
from the beginning of time has used with respect
to visitor logs.
We will comply with both the Federal Records Act
and the Presidential Records Act as stated by law.
The Press: So, why does the President object
to people knowing who is coming in the White House?
Mr. Spicer: It&#39;s not a question of objecting.
It&#39;s about following the law.
We&#39;re following the law as both the Presidential Records Act
and the Federal Records Act prescribe it.
So, it&#39;s the same policy that every administration
had up until the Obama administration, and,
frankly, the faux attempt that the Obama
administration put out, where they would scrub
what they didn&#39;t want put out, didn&#39;t serve anyone well.
The President wants to make sure that people can
come in the same way that they can go into a member
of Congress&#39;s office, provide information and details.
And there&#39;s people who want to be able to come
have that conversation with members of the administration,
the same way that they would do with members of Congress --
go into their office --
The Press: But why didn&#39;t he take this opportunity
to one-up the transparency game?
If Obama was so bad at it --
Mr. Spicer: Because -- I think I&#39;m trying to explain that
to you -- I think that we recognize that there&#39;s a privacy
aspect to allowing citizens to come express their views.
And that&#39;s why we maintain the same policy that every
other administration did coming up here prior
to the last one.
And the last one, frankly, was a faux level of doing
that, because when you go through and you scrub
everyone&#39;s name out that you don&#39;t want everyone
to know, that really is not an honest attempt at doing it.
We are going to follow the law the way that every
administration has followed up until the last one.
Zeke.
The Press: Thanks, Sean.
Following on Kaitlan&#39;s question, the rationale
given Friday for the visitor logs reversal
was for national security and privacy concerns.
Both of those were clear exemptions in the Obama
administration&#39;s policy which led to that
scrubbing that you described.
So, why exactly the reversal?
You seem to be describing maybe a third rationale
that you&#39;re giving.
Mr. Spicer: No, I think I just touched on privacy,
that people have a right --
The Press: The Obama administration had that
exception to their visitor logs.
Mr. Spicer: But I think the problem, Zeke, is that
we don&#39;t know what the -- I mean, they said what it
was, but you don&#39;t know who got left off and who didn&#39;t.
They chose to not put people out for whatever
reason, and they gave an excuse and no one questioned it.
So, the question is -- but I think the bottom line
is, as I said to Kaitlan, is that we&#39;re going to
have the same policy that every President has had
through time and comply with the law on both fronts.
But again, you remember -- it&#39;s interesting that
we&#39;re following basically the same thing that
members of Congress follow.
You go in and you meet with a member of Congress
right now, that there&#39;s an option for people to go in
and express their opinion.
If they want to make it public, who&#39;s meeting with
them -- and in a lot of cases we do, we bring
in you guys to probably a greater extent than has
happened before in terms of the pool spray.
We list participant lists.
But I think there&#39;s an opportunity sometimes
for American people who want to come in and have
a conversation and not become -- and be able
to share their view.
So, again -- but remember, this is the same policy
that every President and every administration has followed.
The Press: I&#39;ll grant you that --
Mr. Spicer: Thank you.
The Press: -- but this President entered office
running a campaign saying he was going to &quot;drain the swamp.&quot;
So, under this existing policy, a lobbyist --
the President has decried on the campaign trail --
Washington insider, members of the swamp
can walk into the White House and there is no recourse for
the public to hold the President to account --
Mr. Spicer: I think you guys -- but the visitor logs
to all the White House components --
OMB, the Council of Economic Equality, U.S. Trade
Representative, Office of Science and Technology --
The Press: (Inaudible.)
Mr. Spicer: Huh?
What I&#39;m saying is all those are subject
to the Federal Records Act.
We&#39;re complying with all that and we&#39;re complying
with the Presidential Record Act.
My point is, that, look, this is the policy that&#39;s
existed from the beginning of time since they were
kept through the last one.
And the last one was a faux attempt at that.
Again, it&#39;s not really being transparent when
you scrub out the names of the people that you don&#39;t want
anyone to know were here.
And so I think that we&#39;ve made a decision to stay
in line with the law and follow the same procedures
that everyone else has maintained.
Trey.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
On North Korea, is the President prepared to act alone,
or does he feel that Congress should be somehow involved
in the process if any decision that includes
the use of force is made?
Mr. Spicer: I think he&#39;s going to utilize
the powers under Article II of the Constitution.
I think what you saw with respect to the action that
he had with Syria, he made sure that members
of Congress were notified of his action in a very,
very short amount of time.
We&#39;re going to continue to seek their input on the policy
overall and then make sure that they&#39;re notified.
We&#39;ll do that.
But I think the bigger consultation issue is what
we do with the larger world community and have
that dialogue, as I mentioned earlier, to make
sure that every country that can is putting
the appropriate level of economic and political
pressure on North Korea to act in a way that helps us.
Eamon.
The Press: Thanks, Sean.
With tax filing day coming up, is the President going
to release his 2016 tax returns, given that we can
assume, maybe, that those are not themselves under
audit, which is the --
Mr. Spicer: No, you can&#39;t, they are.
I think it&#39;s been covered before.
It&#39;s the same thing that was discussed during
the campaign trail.
The President is under audit.
It&#39;s a routine one that continues.
And I think that the American public know
clearly where he stands.
This was something that he made very clear during
the election cycle.
The Press: And to --
Mr. Spicer: Hold on, and then so -- and the one time that it
was done, I think the people understand how successful
the President has been and how much he&#39;s paid in taxes.
But we&#39;re under the same audit that existed,
and so nothing has changed.
The Press: And as you know, the IRS never
comments on individual taxpayer information.
This obviously is an extraordinary case
involving the President of the United States.
The President could authorize the IRS,
presumably, to go ahead and confirm that he&#39;s
under audit and to give us some details about that
audit -- what years, how long is this expected
to take, et cetera.
Will the President authorize the IRS
to confirm that he is indeed under audit?
Mr. Spicer: I think the President&#39;s view on this
has been very clear from the campaign, and the American
people understood it when they elected him in November.
Hallie.
The Press: You got a fly on your head.
Mr. Spicer: Thank you.
Always looking out for me, John Roberts.
The Press: Political leaders in Hawaii
are reviewing plans -- emergency plans in case
they are attacked.
Does the President believe that the level of tension
between the United States and North Korea is at the point
where we should start reviewing emergency attack plans?
Mr. Spicer: So, just to be clear -- and again,
I&#39;m not going to get into -- I would just tell you that
there are military contingency plans for
almost every scenario, in numerous aspects around
the world, here at home -- everything
from humanitarian relief to refugee crises,
to attacks.
That is standard military procedure to have those
kinds of things.
So, to make that in any way, shape or form sound
new would be a mistake.
It is a standard operating procedure of the military
to plan for contingencies in a number of operations,
in a number of hotspots throughout the world
on a regular basis.
And with respect to Korea, in particular, that&#39;s been
going on for decades.
The Press: Sean, how high does the President view
the threat level from North Korea?
Mr. Spicer: Again, I think the President has made
clear we&#39;re aware of the activities that they&#39;ve
engaged in, and we&#39;re monitoring them.
And the national security team continues
to keep him up to date.
The Press: Just one more on that topic.
One of the reasons why successive administrations
have chosen to negotiate with the leaders of North
Korea is because it&#39;s believed that there
are no good military options to deal with it.
Does this President believe that there are
viable military options for dealing with North Korea?
Mr. Spicer: Again --
The Press: Without telegraphing what --
Mr. Spicer: I understand, but I think taking anything on or
off the table is in itself limiting your options
to some degree.
And so, I&#39;m not going to even discuss that.
Julie.
The Press: I wanted to ask you a couple of questions
about the situation in Turkey.
Is the President concerned at all about the reports
from international monitors that this
referendum that gives President Erdogan these
sweeping powers have irregularities in it?
Mr. Spicer: My understanding is there&#39;s an international
commission that is reviewing this and issues a report
in 10 to 12 days.
And so, we&#39;ll wait and let them do their job.
There were international monitors throughout Turkey
and we&#39;ll let --
The Press: And what would he like to see Erdogan do?
Would he like to see a hold right now while
that review happens?
Mr. Spicer: I think at this point -- I don&#39;t think --
I think we&#39;d rather not get ahead of
that report and start to make decisions without knowing.
There were observers there, as there routinely are,
and I&#39;d rather wait and see.
The Press: And just beyond the irregularities,
just the act that Erdogan is going through to try
to accumulate these powers, what does the President make of that?
Mr. Spicer: Again, I&#39;m not going to -- they have a right
to elections and their people participate in that.
Before we start getting into their governing system,
let this commission get through its work.
Steve.
The Press: Sean, when Vice President Pence says,
regarding North Korea, that strategic patience
is over, what does that man exactly?
Mr. Spicer: The era of strategic patience
was a policy that the Obama administration enacted
to basically wait and see.
I think we have now understood that that
policy is not one that is prudent for the United States.
And I think that&#39;s why you&#39;ve seen stepped-up
efforts, particularly with respect to China,
and that&#39;s why I think the relationship that the President
really is building on from the time that he spent down
in Mar-a-Lago with President Xi is hopefully going
to produce results.
And so, part of it is to actively engage with world
partners like China, in particular, that have
economic and political influence that they can utilize.
The Press: What would it take to reach some sort of talks
with North Korea?
Mr. Spicer: Well, let&#39;s see -- again, I&#39;m not
going to get ahead of the policies right now.
I think we&#39;re seeing some active engagement with
China, and that&#39;s helpful.
So, let&#39;s see how that goes.
Hallie.
The Press: I have two for you on North Korea.
You&#39;re doing it today and you&#39;ve done it before --
you&#39;ve stood at the podium and said you don&#39;t want
to telegraph moves that the President will make
to preserve that element of surprise.
A Kremlin spokesperson said that President Trump
is more impulsive and unpredictable than Kim Jong-un.
At what point does this strategy
of unpredictability become a liability?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I respectfully would disagree.
I think that the rest of the world, when he acted
in Syria, in particular, the world community --
not just the world community but here at home,
on a bipartisan basis, applauded the President&#39;s actions.
The Press: So, you see unpredictability as an asset?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think -- absolutely.
But it&#39;s not -- I think that you have to look
at the flip.
I mean, I talked about it a minute ago -- when you look
at some of the actions that we&#39;ve taken
in the past, Mosul being a good example, where we
leaned in and started to explain what we were going
to do and when we were going to do it, that takes
a huge element off the table of not only surprise
but achieving the effect that you&#39;re trying to do.
So, the world community, and especially the more
that he meets with world leaders and developing
relationships, repairing relationships,
and reasserting the U.S. place around the globe,
should be reassuring to not just us here at home,
but around the globe.
People are excited that the President is taking
action, and decisively so.
The Press: You&#39;ve made it clear that you&#39;re not
taking options off the table, including military options.
Defense officials have estimated for a long time
that war on the Korean Peninsula would cost
thousands of lives, it could economically
devastate South Korea.
Is this to be read then as an acceptance of that risk
by the Trump administration?
Mr. Spicer: No.
Again, I think the point is, is that when you get
into a series of hypotheticals about what
you will take on or off the table, will we do this
or not that -- at some point, you really start
to narrow your options.
And I think the President has long held a strategy
that doing that begins to give the enemy,
the opponent, whatever it is in any particular case,
whoever it is, even if it&#39;s just a negotiation,
the options of knowing where to go or where not to go.
And so, the President has been very clear that not
taking options off the table gives us a stronger hand.
The Press: So, do you accept the risk of war?
Mr. Spicer: I didn&#39;t -- no.
Because, again, by what you&#39;re trying to do
is to get us take something off.
I think at the end of the day, we&#39;ll always act
in America&#39;s best interest to ensure that our national
interests are protected.
And so, if we were to say that we&#39;re taking
something off the table in any way, shape or form,
that would limit what we have to do.
We are going to make sure that we do what we have
to do to protect our national interests.
And obviously, with respect to South Korea,
we&#39;ve been very clear -- the Vice President spoke
very clearly about the need to strengthen
and cement the alliance that we have with South Korea
during his visit.
The Press: I just want to be clear, because I want
to flip the coin, right -- which is something you&#39;ve
talked to us about -- if you&#39;re not taking options
off the table, if you flip it then, that can be read
is you&#39;re accepting the fact that that crisis could escalate.
Mr. Spicer: No, I think that&#39;s a stretch.
I think -- that&#39;s the point, I&#39;m not --
The Press: So, you don&#39;t accept that risk?
Mr. Spicer: No, it&#39;s not a question of taking
the risk or not taking the risk.
Again, you can start to go down a very dangerous path
of &quot;will you use this, will you not use that.&quot;
The President is very clear, and I think
everybody who&#39;s been briefed on it, and I think
when you look at the quality of the national
security team that&#39;s surrounding him -- by all
accounts probably the best in our nation&#39;s history
in terms of all across the board -- you know that
the President is getting unbelievably sound and
strategic advice on how to protect our national interests.
Brian.
Mr. Spicer: Last week you dismissed -- I think
it was when Hallie asked a question -- you dismissed
North Korea and said it isn&#39;t a threat if you can&#39;t
go through with it.
So, what changed?
What&#39;s our goal in North Korea?
What&#39;s the strategy?
And what&#39;s your response to the critics who say that this
is just blue smoke and mirrors to hide
some of the problems on the White House staff that
this is a failing domestic social agenda?
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t think there&#39;s anybody in the world
who would not believe that North Korea&#39;s
actions are both provocative and a concern.
So, the actions that we&#39;re taking are extremely --
The Press: But you said that it was --
Mr. Spicer: -- they&#39;re appropriate and justified.
What we&#39;re doing is working with the world community.
And as I mentioned multiple times today,
especially China, which is really acting
in an historic way to ensure that our national interests
and the safety of the Peninsula is protected.
The Press: So, what about the -- well, the follow-up
there is what about the criticism from people on
the Hill who say you&#39;re just hiding a domestic
agenda that isn&#39;t working?
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t -- I&#39;ve never heard that -- I haven&#39;t
heard that criticism --
The Press: Actually, I have.
Mr. Spicer: Okay.
Well, then we travel in different circles.
Look, I don&#39;t think that there&#39;s anybody
who honestly believes that after seeing the launches
that they&#39;re taking and the work that they&#39;re
undertaking, that any attempt to protect our
country and our national interests is anything
other than the right and justified thing to do.
Francesca.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
This morning in an interview, you referred
to the missile launch as an unsuccessful military attack.
That contradicts what other White House
officials have said.
Mr. Spicer: It was an unsuccessful launch.
The Press: Okay, so you just misspoke
in the &quot;Fox and Friends&quot; interview?
There&#39;s no specific evidence that this was
some sort of attack?
Mr. Spicer: No.
It was an unsuccessful missile launch.
The Press: Okay.
Thank you.
Mr. Spicer: You&#39;re welcome.
Glenn.
The Press: Sean, you talked about the end
of strategic patience -- two questions -- in the
context of attempting to expand China&#39;s role
in pressuring North Korea.
Do you believe China has the power to change North Korea&#39;s
behavior if they choose to do so?
And then a follow-up.
Mr. Spicer: That&#39;s a good question.
I think they can definitely try.
There is economic and political points that
they could be pushing.
Whether or not they achieve that outcome
is yet to be seen.
But I think that there&#39;s a lot of influence that they
could exhibit in both of those areas,
and we&#39;ll have to see.
But it&#39;s clearly the prudent thing for
the President to do to try to build that relationship
with President Xi and see if we could achieve
an outcome that&#39;s in all of our best interests.
The Press: How concerned are you that the uptick in
the language, the bellicosity, tweets, could
potentially provoke unintentionally military action?
I mean, is there a concern that a lot of the words
that are being thrown around could have
an unforeseen impact?
Just explain to me what the President is thinking,
how concerned he is of the risk of an unintentional conflict.
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t think that that&#39;s there.
I think we&#39;re taking all the appropriate
and prudent steps.
Jonathan.
The Press: I&#39;ve got a question on North Korea
and China, but first to follow up on the tax question.
You&#39;ve been asked about this obviously a thousand times.
You always talk about under audit --
the President is still under audit.
Is it time to say once and for all the President
is never going to release his tax returns?
Mr. Spicer: We&#39;ll have to get back to you on that.
The Press: I mean, is he -- I mean, really?
Mr. Spicer: Really.
The Press: He may?
Mr. Spicer: No, I said I&#39;d have to get back to you on that.
I think that he&#39;s still under audit;
the statement still stands.
The Press: And on North Korea, you said that China
is playing an active role -- you even said
a historic role -- right now in pressuring the North Koreans.
What are they doing?
Mr. Spicer: Again, I think when you look at the economic
front -- coal, in particular --
that that is North Korea&#39;s number-one export --
The Press: That the Chinese cut off the coal?
Mr. Spicer: I think that they have taken some very
helpful economic actions and exhibited positive
signs on the diplomatic front as well.
But again, this is something that is an ongoing conversation
both on the relationship that the President established
with President Xi.
And I think that we&#39;ll -- as the President has noted
before, we&#39;ll have to see, but it is encouraging,
the signs that China is showing.
The Press: And the President suggested there was
a quid pro quo in terms of not declaring
China a currency manipulator because they
were helping or going to help with North Korea.
So, if China does not adequately put pressure
on North Korea, is he going to go back and declare
them a currency manipulator?
Mr. Spicer: There&#39;s a couple things on that.
Number one, they haven&#39;t been manipulating
their currencies since he&#39;s been in office.
That&#39;s a fact.
Number two is, I think the President&#39;s tweet said clearly
that to do so at this time would not be prudent.
It&#39;s not a quid pro quo.
It&#39;s just saying that in the middle of them taking
very positive signs to help us address the
situation in North Korea, that to label them
a currency manipulator I don&#39;t think would be very
productive in achieving a very, very important
national strategic objective.
The Press: Sean, on both the taxes and the visitor
logs, there are now ethics experts on both sides
of the aisle who say this is the least transparent
administration in decades.
How do you respond?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think that we&#39;ve taken several
steps to allow people access to this White House
in terms of -- in particular the press.
We hold regular pool sprays.
We bring people in.
We release participant lists.
We give press the opportunity to come
into the room, see everybody who&#39;s there.
You&#39;re part of the discussion.
So, I would respectfully disagree with that.
Abby.
The Press: Sean, there&#39;s a new Gallup poll out today
showing that 45 percent of Americans don&#39;t believe
that the President will keep -- only 45 percent
believe he will keep his promises.
That&#39;s down 17 percent since early February.
Given some of his reversals, especially
in the last week, does he risk being seen as a
flip-flopper?
Mr. Spicer: I don&#39;t think so.
I mentioned it on the currency, on NATO --
we talked about this last week.
The question in my mind is looking at the issue
and seeing -- and I mentioned NATO, and I think Matt
asked it last week -- where there are certain things --
and again, on NATO, if you go back to,
I think it was September 29th of last year, he was
talking very specifically about some of the moves
that he was seeing NATO make in a positive
direction, and, already at that point, encouraging them.
In the case of China, they aren&#39;t, since he&#39;s been in
office, manipulating their currency.
The Treasury did issue a report on Friday that put
them on a watch list with a number of other countries.
So, I know that it&#39;s easy to just take an issue and
say, well, he&#39;s not -- make it seem very black and white.
But on these particular issues, you can see that
there&#39;s movement to the President&#39;s position.
I would argue that he&#39;s achieving a lot of results
on the issues that he talked to the American people about.
I think when you talk about the big issues that
he promised the American people in terms of immigration,
we see immigration is down 60 percent at the border;
on jobs, jobs are coming back over and over again,
you&#39;re seeing companies talk about new job creation here,
new manufacturing here.
The executive orders that he&#39;s signing are all
consistent with the promises that he made
to the American people on the campaign trail.
And I think on issue after issue -- whether it&#39;s
immigration, job creation, national security --
the President made very clear promises to the American people
that on -- over and over again, he&#39;s achieving
great success on.
And so, I would argue that we&#39;re going to continue
to see the President not only keep his word but be
rewarded by the American people on that front.
The Press: On a separate issue, about the President&#39;s
continued travel to Mar-a-Lago or any other
place where he&#39;s conducting official business.
Does the White House believe that those other
locations should be treated like this building
in the sense that you guys will be transparent about
who he&#39;s meeting with and what kind of official
business he&#39;s conducting while he&#39;s there?
Is that a commitment that you all are willing to make?
Mr. Spicer: I think we&#39;ve been fairly consistent
with reading out who he&#39;s meeting with and what he&#39;s
done, providing the pool access to his whereabouts
and what he&#39;s doing.
I think we generally do.
Obviously, the President has time to spend
with family and he makes phone calls.
We generally provide readouts of those phone
calls with foreign leaders, whether he&#39;s here or in Florida.
So, I think we&#39;ve done a fairly good job of making
sure that people know who he&#39;s meeting with,
who he&#39;s speaking to, and when appropriate, the contents
of those calls.
The Press: But, Sean, long stretches of time go by
and we get pool reports from the pooler saying,
we&#39;ve been asking the White House
for information about what the President is doing
and we don&#39;t get that information.
We can&#39;t even get an answer to whether he&#39;s
golfing or not these days.
Mr. Spicer: I understand that there are some days
you don&#39;t get it as quick as you want, but --
The Press: Some days we never get it.
Mr. Spicer: Okay, but with all due respect, Julie,
he&#39;s entitled to have moments with his family
and private time.
So, I think, respectfully, I would disagree.
I think we do a very good job of getting
you information, of bringing you along to events,
whether he&#39;s here or at a location or even
going out to dinner.
We&#39;ve lived up to that.
I think the President is entitled to have some times
with his family and friends to just catch up.
The Press: But then that&#39;s the difference then
to what you&#39;re saying to Abby, which is that you
are providing that information.
Mr. Spicer: No, but what I&#39;m saying is,
her question was about official business.
And when he does have a call and when he does meet
with advisors, we generally put it out.
But when he&#39;s meeting internally, in the same
way that when he&#39;s meeting here with his staff, we
don&#39;t read out every staff meeting that&#39;s going on.
And so when he&#39;s down, traveling, and he&#39;s having
meetings -- whether it&#39;s on Air Force One or
wherever -- that&#39;s what his staff does, is they
provide him updates and policy briefings and give
him an opportunity to make key decisions with their
insight into a particular issue.
That&#39;s what all Presidents do.
And I think that I would respectfully suggest that
we have done a really good job of making sure that
the pool in particular is provided information
in terms of his whereabouts, and then we&#39;ve provided
background briefings on issues that are coming up --
where we&#39;re going, why we&#39;re going,
what we intend to do.
So, I get that there&#39;s always going to be this
back-and-forth, you guys are going to always want more.
And I think that we&#39;ve tried to do what we can
to get you that information.
Thank you guys, very much.
We look forward to seeing you in Wisconsin tomorrow,
if you can.
Thank you.
